Fibulae of the Late Roman and Byzantine Era
Classification Maps About Collections Manufacture Fashion & Art Roman Military

Aucissa Fibula

Dates: Most are found to be from the Augustan to Claudian period (10 BCE-50 CE) but can also be found dated later during the Flavian period.

Some of these fibulae have the word ‘AVCISSA’ molded on the head, which is most likely the name of the manufacturer for which this type is named after. This type had a high-arch bow, and the bow was typically flat with a couple ribbed lines going down it. This is also one of the earlier fibula types so it has a simple tube hinge design as well.

Sub-types

Bagendon fibula

Consists of knobs on the sides of the bow.

Two-pin Aucissa fibula

Consists of two pins on each side of the bow.

Wolf fibula

Consists of the bow or foot decorated with a wolf head motif.

Dacian Molded Bow fibula

Consists of ridges on the bow.

Hrusica fibula

Consists of knobs on each side of the head and foot.

Lattice fibula

Consists of the bow having lattice work.

Fibulae of the Late Roman and Byzantine Era

This virtual exhibition lets you explore Roman and Byzantine fibulae. There are collections of Roman Military fibula and Brooches with gems that signify wealth. Throughout this exhibit you can learn about the different types of fibulae as well as how they are made. This is an exhibit that was made for learning and with great interactions to enjoy.
